block.p: Elizabeth Gardiner Offutt, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Ellwood Offutt of Baltimore, was married yesterday to Nicholas Payne Lapham, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony A. Lapham of Washington. The Rev. William P. Billow performed the ceremony at St. Mary's-by-the-Sea Episcopal Church in Northeast Harbor, Me.

The bride, 30, is known as Gardiner. She is a health policy adviser in Washington for CARE, the international relief and development organization. She graduated from the University of Virginia and received a master's degree in public health from Emory University. Her parents work in Baltimore, where her father owns Oxford Associates, an employee-benefits consulting and administration business, and her mother, Susan Offutt, is a sales associate at O'Conor, Piper & Flynn, a residential real estate agency.

Elizabeth Gardiner Offutt, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Ellwood Offutt of Baltimore, was married yesterday to Nicholas Payne Lapham, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony A. Lapham of Washington. The Rev. William P. Billow performed the ceremony at St. Mary's-by-the-Sea Episcopal Church in Northeast Harbor, Me.

The bride, 30, is known as Gardiner. She is a health policy adviser in Washington for CARE, the international relief and development organization. She graduated from the University of Virginia and received a master's degree in public health from Emory University. Her parents work in Baltimore, where her father owns Oxford Associates, an employee-benefits consulting and administration business, and her mother, Susan Offutt, is a sales associate at O'Conor, Piper & Flynn, a residential real estate agency.

The bridegroom, 31, is a senior program officer at the United Nations Foundation, a global philanthrophy started by Ted Turner and based in Washington. He graduated from Yale. His mother, Burkus Lapham, is the chairwoman of Concern Inc., a nonprofit environmental organization in Washington. His father is a partner in Shea & Gardner, a Washington law firm. He was the general counsel of the Central Intelligence Agency in Langley, Va., from 1976 to 1979.
